Her photographs often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. “What is fascinating about Vivian is the number of interesting pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style independently. “Was Vivian sophisticated enough to do this, or did she borrow ideas from those before her?”

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he discovered Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began taking his own pictures. “As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It was the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to make her name known and to include Vivian Maier in the history books.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of attention. Despite being in her twenties, she appeared calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass, and the official asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, leading a council of 12 men to come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded thoughtfully. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels part of the success. There’s a family-like feeling at home, and I received a lot of support from people’s grandmothers.” She also mentioned that it bothers her when people assume her book is not a serious philosophical work.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in a spiral shape, with each part being half the length of the previous one, which makes the story speed up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she aimed to create a book with structural patterns that readers could discover if they wanted to, but that they were not essential to enjoy the story.

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Interestingly, Catton did not plan the story in advance. “I would write myself into a corner and then see how creatively I could get out of the difficult situation I had created,” she said. One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also discussed her love for television dramas, noting how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in writing for screen. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied, her excitement evident in her voice. 

She expressed how being in different places changes her imagination. “I see why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas, to be surrounded by more people.” However, for now, New Zealand will remain her home. I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a child, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either building things in his father's garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has made a living by handcrafting steel-string acoustic guitars. He expresses his fascination with the guitar, wondering how two pieces of wood can create such beautiful sounds and how different types of wood can change the sound. Jonny learned to play his brother's guitar at the age of eleven and later wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. Instead of saving money for one, he decided to build it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and how to assemble them.

Before making the bass guitar, Jonny and his brothers had already built model boats and airplanes, so he was familiar with the process. His father taught them how to use tools like saws and chisels. Jonny had also customized and repaired instruments for his friends. Although his bass guitar turned out well, he had not yet considered a career in guitar-making. He was also interested in painting and sculpture, so after finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university, thinking it would be a good fit for his design interests. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out, feeling too independent for that path. 

Leaving university helped him realize that guitar-making was a form of sculpture that involved creating sound. He believed it was a more practical career than pure art because it produced items that people use. Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. In the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to support himself. His early guitars were sold at the cost of materials, but as he gained a reputation as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, after nearly forty years, he describes his work as "still scratching a living," as he can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the beginning, Jonny focused on getting known in the music community. He attended music festivals on weekends, encouraging musicians to try his guitars and spread the word. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, as he initially struggled with this aspect of the business. Jonny believes that it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were valuable, even though the UK has always had good instrument-making programs. Now, however, UK-made guitars have gained the recognition they deserve.

Jonny thinks that valuable skills can be learned in classes, and he encourages new instrument-makers to take available courses. However, he also believes that there is no substitute for learning through experience. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. For example, if the back of a guitar is too thin or too thick, it will not produce a good sound. He feels that being self-taught allows for a broader understanding, while learning from someone else may limit you to just one method.

Any discussion about English conversation, like any English conversation itself, usually starts with the weather. Following this tradition, I will quote the well-known comment from the eighteenth-century writer Dr. Johnson: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many commentators stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They often make a mistake by thinking that when we talk about the weather, we are genuinely interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not particularly interesting. He notes that in England, we do not experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or blizzards, which are common in other places. Therefore, he finds it hard to understand why the English are so preoccupied with it. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that the English fascination with the weather is not about strong feelings; rather, it is about its unpredictability. He argues that while we may not have dramatic weather, living on the edge of an ocean means we can never be completely sure what the weather will be like.

From my research, I believe both Bryson and Paxman miss the main point: our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather serves as a way for English people to connect with each other. For instance, phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not genuine questions about the weather; they are common greetings or ways to start a conversation. In this sense, English weather talk is similar to "social grooming" among monkeys, where they spend time grooming each other to bond socially.

There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some writers claim that the English talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to break the ice before discussing other topics, or as a fallback topic when conversations stall and there is an awkward silence. This frequent use of weather talk can give outsiders the impression that English people talk about little else. An English conversation might start with a weather-related greeting, include some ice-breaking weather talk, and then return to weather topics when other discussions slow down. This is why people from other countries, and even some English commentators, think that the English are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build a structure that is 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were excited about this trip, choosing it over more glamorous tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they were curious about why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to help her explain life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself.

After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began a new career as an author in 2001. She felt that moving from teaching to writing was a big change. “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very physically demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as exhausting. My former colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories,” she said. Alice aims to fill a gap in children’s fiction. “Much of today’s adolescent fiction focuses on negative experiences. It’s well written, but often dark, or it’s pure fantasy like Harry Potter. My books are different.”

Alice always taught English and History together, using lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy." She is motivated by her love for children. “I’m fascinated by the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested, and then from not understanding to understanding. I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to engage them.” She views her writing as an extension of her teaching.

Alice was inspired to write her first novel partly because she saw a gap in the market, but also because her two sons were leaving home, creating an ‘empty nest’ for her. Additionally, her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years, and she thought it would be good for me. But I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before being accepted into the course, she had to submit her best piece of fiction, which she only learned about a few days before it started. “I quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their unborn baby.” After three hours and 30 pages, she submitted it and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her school’s head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was crucial in editing her book. “My mother-in-law thinks we’re rival authors, but I believe we complement each other. He works with what I’ve written, changing sentence structures and suggesting word changes if something isn’t working. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England, starting at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ending at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high.

As they prepared to start, Jonny expressed his excitement, saying he had never done anything like this before and was looking forward to the beautiful views from the car, especially since it was very cold outside. Alistair, dressed in full winter cycling gear, was also eager but joked about Jonny’s driving skills, saying he might stop for tea during the race.

The race began, and Alistair quickly took off on his bike, heading straight up the hill, while Jonny got into his car and started driving. However, Jonny's confidence was quickly challenged when he encountered a large tractor blocking the road just 15 seconds into his drive. He complained to the cameraman about the delay, saying if Alistair won, it would be because of the farmer.

After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair faced difficulties on the steep slope. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, which was a strange sight for the sheep in the fields. Eventually, Alistair reached the top and was able to pick up speed as he rode down the other side.

Meanwhile, Jonny was dealing with narrow roads and obstacles in the villages, which were not designed for fast driving. He carefully navigated through a narrow corner and a stream on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he sped towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close they were to each other. As Jonny accelerated through the final stretch, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard and finally reached the finish line, looking up to see if Jonny was there. When he found out Jonny had not yet arrived, he celebrated his victory.

A few moments later, Jonny's car pulled up, and he stepped out, congratulating Alistair but expressing his disappointment at losing. "Well done," he said, "I’m gutted."

The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a peaceful atmosphere that separates you from the outside world. This quiet is good for my game. The biggest challenge in a tennis match is to focus only on the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence is broken by applause, cheers, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize there are fifteen thousand people watching every move I make, nor that millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the most important match of my life.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard; I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer won easily, but my defeat in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skill that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it hurts more when you have a chance and let it slip away.

Toni, who is usually tough on me, surprisingly told me there was no reason to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this might be my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment matters, but some moments are more important than others, and I had missed a big one in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to ease my pain. However, he turned out to be right. Another chance came in 2008, just a year later. I was confident I had learned from my previous defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. 

The night before the final, at dinner with family, friends, and my team, we avoided talking about the match. I didn’t explicitly ask them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already mentally preparing for the game. From that moment until the match started, that mental space was mine alone.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” She would spend most of her life in Africa, becoming known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, the National Geographic Society helped make Jane Goodall famous by publishing articles and making documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including popular children’s books and the 1971 bestseller *In the Shadow of Man*, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and interviews tell her story, but they often focus on her personal life rather than her work. 

Despite the many images of her as an adventurous girl or a privileged woman, Jane Goodall should be recognized for her significant contributions to science. Her research has influenced many students who have gone on to important roles in biology. Over her forty-year study, she has gathered a vast amount of data, making her a leading zoologist. Most importantly, she has greatly improved our understanding of the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools, and we did not realize they share similar emotions with humans or have complex social systems. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Her book, *The Chimpanzees of Gombe* (1986), is considered the most important work in chimpanzee research and is the first comprehensive guide on the subject. Her long-term study in Gombe State, Nigeria, is regarded as one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world.

Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we view ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives. Even as a child, there were signs of her future as a biologist. One clear example occurred in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, she disappeared, prompting a search by the police, neighbors, and family. After a frantic search, she returned, covered in straw. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a playful 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to fans of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even very famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are too used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally worked singing jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she recalls, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors are often asked to voice small boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds and to vary her child voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for work is strong, and having a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley advises. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached her level of success – near the top of her field – through determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many children dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and choose more practical careers, such as tax lawyer or auto parts manufacturer. The idea of making a living by drawing simple doodles, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly at first. Yet, some people do just that.

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to be one for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist, with a strong love for comic strips, contributing to school publications, and being known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was fortunate to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. Within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

Becoming a cartoonist doesn’t require much. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even advanced drawing skills. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical barriers are low, the job is still challenging. You should only pursue this career if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to find a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t enjoy. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

Now, let’s talk about the business side of being a cartoonist. There was a time when many cartoonists could find steady jobs with different newspapers and magazines. However, those days are fading. For most people today, cartooning is an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you must not only create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this process, the more successful you will be. I have seen many cartoonists with average creativity but strong business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. However, the reality is that it is more likely no one will be interested in your work. If, by chance, someone steals a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster—it could actually be a lucky opportunity!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of the items I chose to throw away was an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a beautiful, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so I was surprised that I wanted to get rid of it. I took it to the dump and was about to leave it on a pile of trash when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, “You’re not really going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could take it, and I said yes. We parted ways, but I felt sad about my decision for many years.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened the email from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had changed hands many times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion and would have paid anything for it, but his price was very reasonable. I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my belongings, including the guitar. I could imagine my dad laughing at this strange situation.

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the sound of it; it was calming and gentle, and it sounded good even when played by beginners. However, I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played simpler music. This was also the time of punk music, where anyone could be a rock star, even if they weren’t great musicians.

When I opened the box that Keith sent me and took out my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and familiar, though it was smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play but quickly stood up and put the strap over my shoulder, as electric guitars are meant to be played standing. My fingers instinctively knew where to go. I couldn’t explain the chords I wanted to play, but my hands remembered. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to form a chord. 

The electric guitar is usually played in a group. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I should start a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or perhaps I can find others my age who have had similar experiences. We could call ourselves “The Regainers”!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote my book, Insomniac, about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Anyone who struggles with insomnia will tell you that sleep is essential for our mental, physical, and social health. Interestingly, those who have the most trouble sleeping often understand the importance of sleep the best. It is encouraging that sleep is finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. I haven’t seen much discussion about them. We are losing our dreams all the time. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss out on the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the stage where we have the most dreams. Our most vivid and powerful dreams happen during REM sleep, especially just before we wake up in the morning. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, so someone who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years in this stage. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose.

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with the psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was the best way to learn about our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical reasons behind dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of art. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? 

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. Dreams may help us discover new patterns and combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are awakened from REM sleep and asked to respond to a specific word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to think outside the box and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a key part of creativity. I personally find that I write better after having intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely remember, seems to inspire my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t fully understand how it works, but it does seem effective.

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to work well. We must think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, Susie can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. It’s surprising that she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any around,” Susie says with a shrug. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

The reason is that Susie is very popular. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by many famous artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions at auctions, her copies sell for a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie doesn’t reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors truly love art, some are more interested in status. One celebrity likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a “Susie Ray Van Gogh.” “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe and displaying Susie’s copy.

Susie is always honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she aims to make it look as real as possible because she believes doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. However, she signs her name on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and although she knows people who have made money that way, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often get into trouble. Susie admits she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists.

Susie didn’t always work as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden for several years, earning very little. Looking back, she sees that this experience helped her develop her skills and gave her a love for plants, even though it was hard to make ends meet. She had to be very precise and get things right on the first try. She has no regrets about that time but is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to reach her level of skill. Her training allows her to draw anything from plants to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas being her favorites. Susie notes that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she believes that while impressionists painted quickly and freely, they were also very careful, and achieving that balance is quite challenging.

Given her talent, it seems unusual that Susie doesn’t create her own original art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than her copies? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own pieces, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but not impressive. It’s as if she has spent a lifetime enjoying gourmet meals and now finds it hard to settle for plain bread and water. Ultimately, Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. This passion started in her childhood. She felt a strong connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant. People were too curious about her race, and she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This cabin had been her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned her supplies, counting every item, even how many rolls of kitchen paper she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly displayed her unappealing stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her ability to keep her boat clean and organized was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, she views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. A significant moment for her was a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things differently. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt that humanity often takes what it wants and moves on without considering the consequences.

When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a tense conference call. She explained why we need to act now to protect the planet. “Coal, oil, and gas are no longer being made. They are valuable resources we have only once. We need to find ways to use them wisely.” Initially, her message was negative—encouraging people to use less—but she later realized there was a more positive approach. Now, she focuses on reusing materials, passionately discussing things like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, speaking with government and business leaders about our dependence on non-renewable resources. “I will never be an expert,” she admits. “But I am like a sponge, soaking up information. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Compared to this, sailing felt selfish. This is about finding how my voice can be most helpful. It truly matters.”

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and schools to inspire young people to create a sustainable future. “I do miss the adventure of being at sea,” she says. “It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you, and there’s no time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is more complex than just saying, ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.”

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. He hopes to encourage other young people to explore the outdoors instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs both Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to complete the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before turning thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish the challenge before he turns 20.

I spoke with several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They believe that while a young climber might be physically strong, they may not be emotionally ready. They also doubt that a teenager has enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romero family has heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help us. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder about Jordan’s reasons for wanting to climb. Is it just his father's ambition? Paul insists, "This project isn’t about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought it was something to do later in life, but we decided, ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to ensure he still wants to do it." When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal."

In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to break records. This creates a challenge for Jordan. While some may say that focusing on achievements takes away from the enjoyment of climbing, if he wants to inspire others, he needs to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates know as little about classical music as most people our age. If you don’t know who composed the music, you probably don’t own any of their recordings. This situation is concerning for classical music lovers. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical album sells only about 300 copies. This is hard to believe. 

So, why is interest in classical music declining, even though it has existed for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games for this decline, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are not the majority. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music listening is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We prefer fast conversations, quick games, and rapid thoughts. Experts say we struggle to pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Additionally, pop music often deals with topics that interest teenagers, while classical music usually does not.

The way we listen to music has also changed. In the past, families would gather to make music together, and playing an instrument was highly valued. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have increased recently. Maybe, but I doubt many of those new attendees are teenagers. In my orchestra, we perform classical music in various places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more middle-aged people enjoy classical concerts, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people blame schools for teenagers' lack of interest in classical music, but many students are eager to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it is not their preferred music outside of that. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side, so she didn’t hear, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother understood how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among the trees on a hillside; it was quite confusing at first. Then she noticed signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of trailing behind like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be kicked out soon anyway, so I might as well get it over with.” She left the building and walked towards the riding centre, following the sign. 

There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with a sense of respect. She could see they were well cared for. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. Then she noticed the next horse. “But aren’t you the best of the bunch!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” Above the stall was his name: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” 

Bonnie was thrilled to find the room with all the riding gear was unlocked. As she focused on putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything around her. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m serious, I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. “If I stay here, I think we could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling exhilarated as a gentle breeze brushed against her cheek. She sensed that Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his calm confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So, how did a relaxed surfer become a performer in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven.” He remembers that swimming and surfing were his main interests back then. “I was busy with my life. At 13, while in high school, I posted a few videos online.” 

These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans began to comment online, asking for more videos. Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was amazing. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on improving his skills. However, record labels showed interest in him, and he faced a difficult decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. “It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” 

He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m the quiet kid,” he recalls, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.” So, Cody packed his bags and moved with his family across the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. 

Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to stay grounded. Everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight and travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” 

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to opportunities, even when it’s scary. “Everything happened so quickly and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and performing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans. It’s something many people dream of achieving. But I know it won’t last forever.”

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags into place. Last week, I had worked long hours with most of the adults in town, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather, however, didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand still on the curtain, I scanned the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice further downstream. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned as I watched him trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is more special to me than having a famous grandfather, as only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have the diary he kept during that trip, which I read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his bedroom. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. I tried to ignore his anger, but it was getting harder. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His harsh words hit me hard, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came in with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself at the moment,” I finished for her. I wanted to say he had always been like this, but I tried to be understanding. When I was younger, he was my hero, especially when he showed me photos of himself in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, along with his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

Mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried towards the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study, where she saw an unframed painting on the table, leaning against the wall. It was clearly one of Grandpa's works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." 

Jess looked closely at the painting. It showed a river that took up most of the scene; it wasn't a river she recognized and might not even be real, just a fantasy. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, with just a hint of green that made the viewer focus on the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant image. Still, she found it captivating, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that showed her excitement, even though she tried to sound casual. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings; he just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt strangely significant to her, but she couldn't explain why. 

Then she noticed something else. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." 

"Exactly. It's strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later since he hasn't finished it yet. I made the mistake of asking him about it." 

"Mum! You should have known better." 

"I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess his response." 

Jess didn't need to guess; she knew what Grandpa would say. "He told you it's not the artist's job to explain a painting because each one has its own life and language, just like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. He said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to every fool..." 

"… every ignoramus," she added. 

"… every ignoramus about what it means. If artists had to explain their work to everyone who asked, they would never get anything done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." 

"Inspire?" 

"Yes, someone who motivates an artist." Jess understood the term. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse wasn't helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. 

"He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally gone into the carpet and made a big cut. That’s something that could have happened, but I’m not saying it did. I just want to clarify that I didn’t intend to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as often happens. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This kind of thing happens to me quite often. I feel unlucky in that way.

What I was really doing was trying to find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. My grandmother gave me the cabinet when she moved from her house to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and it has tiny glass doors. My grandmother used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. Now, I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. My grandmother knew I loved her corner cabinet, so I was very excited when she gave it to me!

The problem is that it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom belongs to my parents, the back one is my sister Angela’s, the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s, and my room is the size of a broom cupboard. My mother says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. Then, when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be stuck in my small room for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit my grandmother’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. I thought, if I can’t cut anything off the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

The novel "The Borrowers" tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" items from regular-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of this novel, I knew it would be challenging to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how everything should look. I relied a lot on the original illustrations because I wanted to avoid criticism for getting it wrong.

The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans'. This made filming more complicated. A key aspect was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on their borrowing adventures, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans!

We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. One major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it.

The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really embraced the idea. The coins we used were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which often made the crew laugh. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to be pushed down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. 

Getting the costumes right was very important to me, and it had been a challenge for other directors in previous adaptations. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they would stick out like doll clothes. This made it very difficult for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because regular fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show how they should look, and by the end, I had created 2,000 drawings. They weren’t perfect, but they were helpful. 

We didn’t have enough budget for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly; once, I filmed an entire scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. In the end, everything came together, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will take for the chaos to start. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who will ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life of touring and private tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet regular kids for a change. I want to meet kids with parents who have normal jobs, like working in an office or cutting grass. That would be so cool and normal.

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the school secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s one good thing; few people recognize my last name because my dad uses his stage name. “What grade?” she asks. “Eleventh.” “One moment, it’s printing,” she replies. Then she tears the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature is my first class. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. But I’ll be late. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map the night before so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes.

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my very normal outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. No one will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with tan embroidered flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we will read this year, she actually lets us socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is.

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options. Should I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Essence? I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies are easier. “What does he do?” she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, fiddling with the zipper on my backpack. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care much. Great.

Not only is the average American teenage girl expected to be the president of the Student Council, but she also needs to have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America today. Both boys and girls cannot just go to school and blend in; being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and not having high ambitions is seen as laziness. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, points out that many adults forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have a lot of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life. Despite these stresses being common, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label an entire generation this way.

Kristen Loose believes that many people wrongly assume teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She admits to having her phone nearby most of the time, but not for trivial reasons. For her, it is a tool that helps make life easier. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and to be reachable at all times, which can create the impression of a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere, and instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might be listening to language lessons.

Schoolwork and other activities now require attention around the clock, which adds to the burden on already busy teenagers. Many start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish after midnight. Their schedules are filled with school, after-school activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They then have to wake up and do it all over again the next day, often getting less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended amount of sleep, and 28 percent admitted to falling asleep in school about once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends this time on social media or TV; instead, she dedicates it to volunteer work. She thinks the stereotype of teenagers is that they are self-centered and only care about their own interests. However, she enjoys volunteering and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community.

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and push the world forward. There will always be a new generation of students making a difference before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this small group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This ongoing science project combines astronomy with adventure, which is likely why teenagers are drawn to it. I joined them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to release a high-altitude balloon to capture images of shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail of light.

As night falls, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon. Inside, there is a camera, an altitude measuring device, and a thermometer to track temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers are placed on the outside of the lunch box to help them find it later. They use a gas tank, donated by a supporter from a nearby state, to inflate the balloon, which gradually expands to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get the tank, but he didn’t mind. For the kids in this club, such efforts are normal.

Finally, it’s time for lift-off. They count down, “Five, four, three, two, one,” and the balloon starts to rise. Some of the teenagers run after it, shining powerful flashlights to track its path in the dark sky. There is a moment of silence and a shared sense of wonder as the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch for shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside, gazing at a sky so clear that it’s hard to believe they are only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I see a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” one girl whispers. “I know,” replies another. Suddenly, a meteor streaks across the sky.

As the balloon rises, the air pressure decreases, causing it to expand until it nearly reaches the size of a house. Then it pops with a loud bang. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will retrieve it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” says the group’s leader, noting they have only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “This journey helps us get to know the landscape in a way we normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box landed on a high peak or in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader explains. “What seems wild and risky to some is just a normal part of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box, which was in a canyon on a flat rock near a waterfall. Unfortunately, the camera did not capture any shooting stars. While this was disappointing, it provided a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and their effects above mountain ridges. It also became another exciting story to share with anyone who asks.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she turned fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a phase she had not gone through. She helped him with a science project and found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology that amazed her. She realized that this was a field she wanted to pursue.

I asked Chloe about the support she received, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people at that time. She recalled meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite his youth. Although she was nervous, he was friendly and patient, which made her feel more comfortable.

I also asked Chloe about how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows. She expressed that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but they often misrepresent palaeontologists. She feels that they are usually shown as either quirky geniuses or socially awkward individuals, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explained that her job is very diverse. She spends time digging for dinosaur bones, working in laboratories to analyze fossils, and writing scientific papers. Although not always required, she believes it is important to communicate scientific findings to the public, especially to young people. She wants to inspire them to learn about science, using dinosaurs as a way to spark their interest in the natural world.

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She noted that the producers were knowledgeable, and her role was mainly to ensure accuracy, such as confirming that the dinosaurs depicted lived during the same time period. The documentary attracted viewers of all ages because it presented dinosaurs in a way that was much more realistic than in movies like Jurassic Park.

Chloe believes that dinosaurs continue to captivate us and remain a focus of research because they appeal to our sense of exploration. They represent the unknown and the excitement of discovery. In a world that feels smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to learn, and Palaeontology offers a unique way to explore the past.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are just six years old, you probably know that you are not “there yet,” even if you keep asking, “Are we there yet?” The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not “there” anymore; it’s “here.” So if you think you might be “there,” you should really be asking, “Are we here yet?” I’m sure no one wishes to be “there” more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long trips.

Think about it: wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the beautiful views outside. Meanwhile, your parents are in the front seat, managing snacks and the radio, making sure everything runs smoothly.

But then, something unexpected happens—usually caused by my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat. I can’t let that happen, so I put my foot on his side. Soon, he’s invading my space, and a fight breaks out. Our parents have to reach back to separate us while driving, telling Tim to stay in his own seat. This calms things down for a bit, and we continue to enjoy the scenery.

Later, while I’m trying to read, I feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing air in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry, and the tension rises again. Tim gets scolded, and the car swerves a bit. Eventually, things calm down again.

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he often replies, “Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.” When we point out that we are still on the highway, he says, “Oh, then maybe we’re not there yet.” This usually keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell when you finally arrive because the adults quickly get out of the car and move away from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is no, you are not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope that customers will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There’s so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve staring at screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate with each other.”

The games played in their café are called ‘Eurogames’. These games often have gentle themes, like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was further developed in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players either win or lose together, encouraging more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings, which is based on the famous book. He recalls, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something similar.”

Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. He enjoyed receiving games as birthday gifts but often felt disappointed when they didn’t meet his expectations. With help from his game-loving uncle, he began redesigning games to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up introduced even more storytelling. Leacock explains, “It’s like an electronic game where you develop characters, gain new rules, and the story evolves.”

Interestingly, the rise of video games has helped the popularity of modern board games. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to playing board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a major games company, says, “Everyone plays mobile games now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.” 

For a while, video games allowed for social interaction in places like arcades or through multiplayer games played together in the same room. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became more distant from each other. This led some people to seek out ways to play games with others in person again. 

As seen in John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now something to be shared directly and physically, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are important in the music industry, even if your career starts with many setbacks. He mentions that his mother was an "amazing singer" who encouraged him to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was one aimed at middle-aged people, which influenced his musical taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a modern song. Around the same time, he had to choose between playing tennis, which he did at a national level, and pursuing music. He spent his school lunchtimes in the music room learning songs on the piano. He recalls, "I was quite good at tennis, but it wasn’t what I wanted to do for my whole life. It was just too much hard work."
