At 17, he left school to become a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as passionate about performing. Jamie remembers telling his parents, "This is what I want to do. I’ve been writing lyrics in economics class and playing the piano every day while others were outside." His father gave him 18 months to succeed in music; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After several close calls with record labels, he was signed by a music publisher at 19 based on one song. However, the labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Eventually, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album, but fame did not come right away. He reflects, "I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for much of my artist career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time." Writing for other artists is where he truly found his success. He believes he is one of the main writers that UK labels turn to for new artists, helping them launch their careers.

Sometimes, he has to reassure the artists he works with that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks them, "Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He emphasizes that they should aim to create something amazing that will also sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write hit songs. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply understands that he wants to write number one hits and has the talent to do so. Instead of worrying about how others perceive him, he focuses on his goals. He states, "When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for global success and write the best music for next year. It’s not just about what’s trendy; we want to create classic modern pop songs."

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him because we don’t watch videos of people doing bike stunts. He is known as a ‘street trials cyclist.’ This means he jumps from difficult places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other challenging spots. These stunts are recorded and shared online.

On the day I interview him, we meet at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids all recognize him, and several older people come over to show their respect, calling him ‘an absolute legend.’ After watching him perform, I agree with them. Even though I came with some doubts, I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and sometimes I can’t believe he will succeed. However, when I compliment him afterward, he seems uninterested and a bit down.

Despite his online fame, Tony says he is not comfortable with being a celebrity. He finds the social aspect challenging. He understands the importance of connecting with fans, but he prefers to focus on doing stunts rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that capture his stunts. He reflects, “This technology allows people like me to earn a living.” He feels that many people are always recording themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t fully agree with that.

Tony is not complaining, though. He makes a good income from his videos, which would have just been a hobby for someone in the past. After years of interviewing top athletes, I’ve learned that two key factors turn a passionate child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle emotional disappointment. These traits can be more important than talent and help someone keep going despite failures. In riskier sports, it is even more important to have mental strength.

Even at the park, Tony fell a few times on what he considered easy but new challenges. He simply got back up and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, “Those who criticize me may be worried, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know much about the sport. They don’t realize I get advice from experts to reduce risks.”

In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some never feel scared, and they shouldn’t be doing these sports. It’s important to recognize the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can overcome fear and those who can’t. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes, I ride around for a while to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, I’ll be fine.”

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 

Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Although she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!”

On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterward. “I’m glad it’s over!” Despite this experience, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had previously written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and also used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, “That trip opened my eyes,” and decided he wanted to see the world by bike. Instead of a regular touring bike, he wanted to build one himself. He thought the most unique bike would be a penny farthing, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made.

After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. He met other cyclists who could ride up mountains, but he never regretted using his penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more people were amazed by his bike.

His toughest experience was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, “If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.”

I work at a university in the US with my team, and we are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have recently started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’ that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their population has decreased significantly, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about their activities during the day, but we know very little about what they do at night because we did not have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, allowing us to learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat.

Our work is challenging. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in various locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites to record every duck I see. The weather has been difficult; some nights are warm, but most are rainy. It is so quiet that I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. Despite the challenges, I enjoy this work, especially when I think about the summer, which will involve long hours in a laboratory analyzing our results together. Being inside will be tough, but it is necessary, and I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!

Whenever I tell people about my job, they often find it hard to believe it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my workdays tasting chocolate! Tasting is a crucial part of ensuring that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate from my company. Each week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I need to check them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to select the best ones for our chocolate. 

Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I keep my colleagues happy by sharing samples! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients to experiment with. It’s great to have a private space to go to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I enjoy the variety and lack of routine in my work, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part! 

People often ask me if I ever get bored of chocolate. I’ve worked with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and enjoy more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it offers many different skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching objects like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can attend some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “To have a career in the circus, performers need to avoid doing the same thing repeatedly – it’s essential to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to be successful in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendships formed with other performers and the opportunity to learn from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who are determined to succeed, have creativity, and continuously work on improving their skills. 

People often think that circus performers are likely to get injured or that they only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns that it’s not a profession for making a lot of money! “The work usually does not provide a regular salary. It’s also competitive – but it’s a lot of fun!”

You may not know her name or face, but you have likely heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, which means she sings in the background to support the main singer. Many people think backing singers are not as talented as lead singers, but that is not true—they often have to be even better. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry!

“What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she says. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might even be a silly tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are very important for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There is often no sheet music to follow. I will never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was scared because I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough!”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers sometimes do not know which musical range works best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”

Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion, but she built a successful business selling ‘satchels,’ which are traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous shops and are popular among many celebrities. Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, such as cake decorating and party planning, instead of just going with her first thought. 

When she chose to focus on satchels, not everyone supported her idea. Julie recalls, “Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.” She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks. 

Although Julie was not familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products grew, along with the speed at which her company produced the satchels. Now, Julie enjoys waiting to see which celebrity will be seen with a satchel next!

While other companies spend money on online advertising, Julie uses the internet community to gather ideas for new and exciting styles. There was a difficult time when another company copied her satchel design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now ensures she has confidence in her production team, just as she does in her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices, where people enjoy working. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes the workplace special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky enjoyed playing many sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach believed she had the potential to become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork. 

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky found this exciting and decided to try cycling too. She later said it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The cycling track was close to her school, so attending training sessions after school was easy for her. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. When she turned 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, “For years, I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it all. When the excitement fades, it loses its meaning. Fortunately, I found a new career.”

Vicky now works for a charity called CycleZone. She said, “We help young people who have never enjoyed sports. The first thing we do is teach them how to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does important work and brings young people together, making them feel part of a larger community.” The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky mentioned, “Some people doubt that celebrity support is always good for a charity. They argue that celebrities may be more interested in their own image, which can distract from the charity's real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I believe they should.”

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, music was always present in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school, and she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. This teacher suggested that Ana join the school theatre club to build her confidence. After participating in the club for some time, she happily sang with 50 other students at a concert at the end of the term.

A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Although she was the youngest student, she already knew more about music than many of her classmates. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her ideas, which inspired her to write the song "Something to Say" about her frustration. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled when people commented that they loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened.

Joss Alton, the owner of a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join his company. At first, Ana was unsure because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss convinced her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope, and all the tickets sold out quickly, making it a wonderful evening.

Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments, as she feels she has more to express during those times. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how unhappy it made him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her music, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist, like me, and wanted to write articles about the journey. He loves boats, which is not something I share with him. However, I had always dreamed of visiting this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because it was where our great-grandparents lived before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before our trip, there were storms in the area we were going to. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our time there predicted calm seas. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry assured me he would handle everything, so I stopped worrying.

After we arrived in Canada, we met the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast now, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was wonderful to forget about how fast or slow the day was going. We always remembered to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. Each evening, when we fell asleep on the boats, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life!

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends if I stayed. I was also excited to share our adventures with everyone back home!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a child, I went to many of his games. You might think that watching so many matches would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I often brought a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training sessions, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I found myself in a game against another school. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trained Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn’t enjoy being away from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t too different for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted that decision.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was quite expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my hometown, Chicago, USA. This job involved showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see the city I had lived in all my life from the perspective of tourists, and it felt like a new experience each time!

After I finished my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I looked into it, I realized I needed to learn a lot more to get a license as a full-time guide. All tour guides in Chicago must be able to answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent guide.

Being a tour guide is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in busy areas. There are many other important skills. You need to be entertaining and tell engaging stories. Most importantly, you must be able to adapt to unexpected situations, like if a place you planned to visit is closed or if the route changes. Tourists don’t want to hear about problems; they just want to enjoy a well-organized tour.

I have to ensure that visitors are happy with my tours, as negative reviews online can harm my business. Like many tour guides, I understand that good reviews are crucial because they attract more customers. That’s why it’s essential to make tours enjoyable and stress-free. I believe that the enthusiasm and energy I bring to my job help me receive great reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I traveled to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were all older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first experience doing something like this. However, we ended up having a great time.

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it quite challenging, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meals made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river using large brushes and soap. I found this very enjoyable, even though I ended up getting wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they would spend the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, which was a bit cramped, but we chose to do this because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we were prepared for that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both do not like.

After dinner, all the volunteers and staff would spend the evenings talking and playing games. Now that we are back in the UK, Josie doesn’t often mention Thailand. However, if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I’m not sure she is being completely honest, though. I think she might feel a bit frustrated with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she reflects on the experience, she realizes how lucky she was to go. Maybe she will return one day – I definitely will!

I’m Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just to people for their homes or gifts, but to many different customers. Hotels and offices often use flowers in their reception areas, and we sometimes provide flowers for businesses' advertising photos. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I felt very proud of what we accomplished.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be quite cold and dark, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The beautiful sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were picking for myself, I would probably choose only pink flowers because it’s my favorite color. However, I have to remember that my preferences may not match what my customers want. 

Sometimes, it’s difficult to find the flowers that customers want because not all flowers are available all year round. I don’t enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it’s part of the job. Flowers can be expensive, so I try to get the best price I can. 

Back at the shop, we check customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought into vases. Then, we create flower bunches and calculate the costs of the orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some people might think this is too much work, but I enjoy figuring out how to create the best flower arrangements for the budget someone has. That’s what selling is about, and I wouldn’t want to do anything else!

My city has a modern cinema that shows the latest films and many children's movies on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized I wanted something more – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we rented an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created a great atmosphere for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are even free because the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs without trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can also track ticket sales online, so we don’t worry about empty seats anymore! There is always a lot to do, but it feels wonderful when people of all ages tell us how much they enjoyed the experience. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now connected with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to learn how they operate, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We also started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local reviews. We have tried putting up posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – when people recommend us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film; last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed.

Taking photographs was always my favorite activity as a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I started a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began. 

After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that people liked my unique perspective. I enjoyed photographing many different subjects. Then, someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better. I agreed and decided to focus on nature, especially birds and the sky. 

Most of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they preferred color. This made me doubt my project at times, and I almost gave up. However, I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices. 

One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for my age group, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges announced that I had won first prize. I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my choice of career.

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. These were things I had never done before. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities that challenge you, and you are always learning. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you complete each level, you receive a certificate.

When I first joined, my leader suggested that my first challenge should be to help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to accept the challenge because I wanted to earn my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I completed the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed great relationships with the children. Now, I spend about four hours a week there, and I always look forward to it.

Because of what I learned at the children’s club, I have decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about this career before starting at the club. In fact, I had never considered my future job, and the idea of youth work had never crossed my mind. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, and yes, one of them is for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The slope looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to ask him if I could start, but he loved the sport and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I did well. After that first experience, I quickly fell in love with snowboarding and improved my skills. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my passion for competing and winning has only grown stronger as I’ve aged, which motivates me to work harder.

I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well. For example, I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I didn’t think I would attempt the difficult jumps that earned me that score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and my studies since there’s no snow. I train every day, but I don’t have to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends, which helps me cope with not being able to do what I love most.

I need to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I believe it’s important to have another career option in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is possible if my active lifestyle allows me to attend college. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only get it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am very thankful to my parents for making me do that because it taught me an important lesson.

I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much. My parents suggested I start my own small business instead. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it too. I never thought I would find it easy, as it looked complicated when I watched my mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me that I could create something nice at home with simple tools and materials.

I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I was happy they bought them, I still needed to be sure they looked good enough for other people to want them. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewellery to take home to their families and friends. Soon, we started getting calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but we were just two people at a market stall!

That was when I realized my business could succeed, and it was time to take the next step – creating a website. Since then, I have made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It has been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly inspired by Janine’s own life. In an interview, she explained, “Because my father’s job made us move around the country a lot, I learned how to make new friends easily. I know what it feels like to be the new student in a class, which helped me write about Amelia’s experiences in a new school. Some of the funniest moments in the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to use my imagination to create that.” 

Janine started writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she had won a short story competition on a young writers’ website. This is why, when she finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publishing company, they were eager to read it. They loved the book, and a year later, it was available in bookstores.

One review of Being Amelia notes that, even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer mentioned that, despite Janine’s young age and the book’s short length, she has shown that she is a better writer than many bestselling authors. Janine is still adjusting to her fame: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s fine. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to discover what works for them. For me, I just need to spend time with my friends, and I’ll soon find something interesting to write about!”

My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved into a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was excited about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should accept the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home across the water, and there was no school nearby.

However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle is not particularly beautiful, but our apartment inside it is comfortable. In the summer, the island feels very lively because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live on the island, but there are not as many teenagers as I had hoped. The adults support each other and help with repairs, which often requires a lot of hard work.

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to the stormy days with big waves, but the ferries do not run then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I will miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my school friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! 

Despite these challenges, we often enjoy amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it is so foggy that you cannot see anything, but then, within hours, it can be bright and sunny again. This still feels incredible, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do experience terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to withstand them. But then I remind myself that it has been here for centuries and is still standing strong!

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best spots to see them. It was incredible, and when we returned home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving it. During family holidays abroad, I have had the chance to see birds from other countries as well. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I have been to Egypt, and last summer we traveled to South America, where I hoped to see my 200th species. I wasn’t too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I have learned that patience is important in this hobby. I shared a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it interesting and commented positively. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before I walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and that they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year! I feel lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not consider becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually many birds to see, especially in areas with lots of greenery. I also believe that birdwatching clubs should work to attract more young people to this hobby. Everyone should connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to be expensive.

I began playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. I even started dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. 

The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one of the referees saw that I had talent. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her club. I was surprised at first because I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I began regular training with a big club when I was just 13. After that, I improved a lot. 

Still, some people doubted I would ever become a star player, which made me a little sad. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and to believe in my abilities. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let my teammates down. By chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with a large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my teammates carried me around the pitch. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals.

Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to meet other players from my club. It will show them what a professional environment is like and inspire them to believe they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me: there will be good times, but also some challenges. Fortunately, I have faced very few challenges, so I consider myself lucky!

One of the most interesting changes in education in the UK and around the world in recent years is the push for new students to get involved in research as soon as they start their studies. This change acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists making new discoveries, but is also a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills will be helpful not only in your studies but also in your future jobs, as they help you think critically about the world and how to approach your work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge involves asking questions instead of accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, opinions, or beliefs we encounter? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes and new knowledge. However, research can also start from simple inquiries that involve careful work, thoughtful questions about issues, and practical suggestions. Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done research for school projects or answered questions at work since you began studying. You have asked questions that required investigation, whether you were deciding where to go on holiday, how to grow plants, fix things at home, train your dog, or find the right music system online.

In college and higher education, you are expected to have an inquisitive mind, identify problems and questions, critically explore and evaluate information, and create your own responses and knowledge to contribute to discussions. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning comes from listening to teachers and texts. It may feel disrespectful to question established knowledge or authority, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn. However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

This process of inquiry and knowledge creation can seem overwhelming. Critical thinking is especially important in research. The research done by others is valuable for students, academics, and professionals, but we must not simply repeat what we read or accept everything as fact. Instead, we should engage with the information, think critically about it, test it, and determine if it is logical and supported by evidence. We should avoid relying blindly on the facts and information provided by others in our readings or discussions.

Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity. In the 18th century, coffee houses in London were places where people discussed science and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artists like Pablo Picasso talked about modern art. However, living in a city can be challenging. The same cafés that encouraged discussion also contributed to the spread of diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. 

Today, cities are known for their creativity, but they can also feel overwhelming and unnatural. Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. While it has been known that city life can be tiring, new research shows that living in cities can actually reduce our ability to think clearly. One major reason for this is the lack of nature in urban environments. Studies have shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even small views of nature can help our brains by providing a break from the stress of city life.

This research comes at a significant time: for the first time in history, more people live in cities than in rural areas. Instead of enjoying open spaces, we are packed into concrete environments filled with strangers. It has become clear that these unnatural surroundings can negatively affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. 

When walking down a busy street, our brains must manage many distractions, like other pedestrians and traffic. This constant need to pay attention to so many things can be exhausting because it forces our brains to work hard to decide what to focus on. The brain is like a powerful computer, but paying attention uses a lot of its energy. In contrast, natural environments require less mental effort. This idea is known as attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can help restore our attention because natural settings have elements that naturally attract our focus without causing stress.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the negative effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban areas. Parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a much-needed escape from city life. A well-designed park can enhance brain function in just a few minutes. While many have looked for ways to boost mental performance, such as energy drinks or office redesigns, nothing seems to be as effective as simply taking a walk in nature.

Given the many mental challenges caused by city living, one might wonder why cities keep growing. Even in our digital age, cities remain important for intellectual life. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same crowded features of cities that can lead to attention and memory problems—like busy streets and close proximity to others—are also linked to innovation. Scientists believe that the “concentration of social interactions” is key to urban creativity. Just as the crowded streets of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy environment of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, supports its role as a hub for technology and creativity. 

The challenge is to find ways to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its unique advantages. After all, there will always be moments when someone might say, “I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!”

Where should we search for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques that support this idea. However, I believe there is no strong reason to limit the study of the mind to just the brain or body. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that items like stone tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have significantly influenced human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, I propose that what exists outside our heads may also be part of our minds. 

It is understandable why we often connect the mind with the brain. Most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their surroundings. This approach is practical for neuroscientists, especially when using brain scanners. However, this often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I do not intend to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to emphasize that the mind is more than just the brain. 

Instead, we should consider the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes into play. MET explores how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be integrated into our bodies. For example, when we create numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool, we are engaging with materials in a cognitive way. 

MET also looks at how these interactions have changed since ancient times and what these changes mean for our thinking. This perspective provides new insights into what minds are and how they are shaped by the things around us. 

Consider a blind person using a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick illustrates how minds and objects can be seen as interconnected. It also shows the flexibility of the human mind: by using the stick, the blind person transforms touch into a form of sight, and the stick itself plays an active role. The sensation felt at the tip of the stick connects the person to the environment, leading the brain to treat the stick as part of the body.

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can adapt and change significantly by incorporating new technologies. I view the human mind as an ongoing project, always evolving. It is essential to remember that, regardless of what form the “stick” has taken throughout our history—whether it be ancient stone tools or modern technology—its main purpose is to connect us to the world rather than to limit us.

Through these “sticks,” humans explore, learn, and understand their environment, while also shaping their future. This is different from how monkeys use sticks to get food. For humans, “sticks” are tools for satisfying our curiosity. This unique human ability to engage with material culture explains why we create things and how those creations, in turn, shape our minds. I call this concept metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and develop as they interact with the material world.

I aim to reintroduce the importance of materiality in understanding cognition. MET provides a new perspective on how various forms of material culture, from ancient tools to modern smartphones, have played a crucial role in defining and transforming who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to realize that humans have been using such technology since our earliest days.

Few inventions have changed civilization and our understanding of the world as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of culture at all levels—practical, scientific, industrial, and artistic. It also opened up a new world of entertainment. Historians argue that photography is the greatest contribution of the US to the visual arts, as no other art form has had such a significant impact.

To fully appreciate photography's influence, we need to look at its origins in the mid-19th century. Why was this new art form so attractive? First, photography was a mechanical process that matched the growing interest in technology, reflecting a national attitude that embraced change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes in an immediate and exciting way.

Second, the camera became the preferred tool for expressing identity, allowing individuals to present themselves to the public in a society that constantly reinvented personal and national identities. Third, the camera played a crucial role in creating and preserving family memories, even if those memories were somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs aligned with a broader artistic trend towards realism and the depiction of everyday life in US art.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. Because photographs are created by machines, they are records of events, people, and objects, which gives them a sense of objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by a specific person, it also carries a subjective point of view. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize its subject, leading to the idea that photography is a "universal language." Yet, the meaning of a photograph is more complex. 

Few subjects—people, objects, or events—speak for themselves, and every image comes with context that shapes our understanding, such as captions in newspapers or layouts in magazines. To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and role within its cultural context: Why did the photographer take the picture? How was it first seen? Additionally, the same image can have different meanings depending on where and when it is viewed.

While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear. In recent decades, starting with artist Andy Warhol's use of photographs in his work, many artists have incorporated photography in various ways. In summary, photography has become an essential part of art, complementing painting and shaping our ideas of representation even before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician known as one of the founders of modern psychology, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of what this means. Although we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains a complex concept. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and a way of knowing about these elements. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own experiences, which may or may not align with scientific facts.

Because of this, we often make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We act like amateur psychologists when we share opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing is effective or why people behave in certain ways, like feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems can arise when two people interpret situations differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in specific situations. Psychologists help us differentiate between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

While psychology studies the mind and brain, psychologists do not yet fully understand how the brain works in relation to our emotions and behaviors. It is often difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective, but the mind's workings are not easily observable. Instead, we can only infer them from behavior, similar to solving a crossword puzzle by interpreting clues.

Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and influence the processes it studies. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply findings to real life. Psychological research has been beneficial in various areas, such as improving reading methods for children, designing safer machine controls, and helping emotionally distressed individuals communicate their feelings better.

Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation began only in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions, focusing on identifying mental structures. While this remains an interest, introspection has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only reveals a small part of the brain's automatic functions. William James compared introspection to trying to see in the dark by turning up the gas quickly. Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than solely on their own experiences.

In a storehouse located in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, there exists a unique collection known as the Museum of Failed Products. This collection, owned by a company called GfK, includes items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, which were taken off the market because few people wanted to buy them. The museum's owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product represents a story of disappointment for the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved.

What is surprising is that this museum operates as a successful business. Many companies do not keep samples of their failed products, showing how uncomfortable they are with discussing failure. The museum was started by Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, who initially wanted to create a library of consumer products, not just failed ones. He began collecting new items in the 1960s, not realizing that most products fail. As a result, his collection ended up being mostly unsuccessful products.

Today’s optimistic culture likely contributes to the products found in the museum. Each product likely went through meetings where no one recognized its potential failure. Even if they did, marketers might invest more money into a failing product to save face. There is often little effort to understand why a product failed, and people involved may choose to forget about it.

This focus on optimism is also common in the self-help industry, where the idea of "positive visualization" is popular. This concept suggests that if you imagine positive outcomes, they are more likely to happen. Research by neuroscientist Tali Sharot indicates that our brains may be wired to see positive outcomes as more likely than they actually are. Her studies show that well-adjusted people often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events compared to those who are depressed.

However, how effective are these positive thoughts about the future? Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have explored this question. Their findings reveal that spending time imagining successful outcomes can actually reduce people's motivation to achieve their goals. For instance, people who were encouraged to visualize a productive week at work ended up accomplishing less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck suggests that our experiences with failure depend on our beliefs about ability. Those with a "fixed mindset" believe that ability is something you are born with, while those with a "growth mindset" think it can develop through effort and challenges. People with a fixed mindset often find failure very distressing, seeing it as proof that they are not as capable as they thought. For example, a talented athlete who believes they are naturally gifted may not practice enough to reach their full potential. In contrast, those with a growth mindset view failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger by being challenged. Ultimately, having a growth mindset is a more positive way to approach life, regardless of whether it leads to success.

Text: 'Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many of us think we understand, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we once accepted as true is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists want to discover what helps players perform their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. At the same time, those who invest in sports want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

This raises questions for fans. For example, would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. This belief may lead them to confuse cause and effect. When a team plays well, home fans cheer loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal, causing even more excitement. Fans often remember the times they cheered when a goal was scored, forgetting the many times their cheers did not lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that scientific evidence supports. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct their energy towards the referee. In a well-known study, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another version without sound. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. The researchers concluded that referees try to avoid extra stress from making calls that upset the home crowd. They do not simply follow the crowd's wishes; they aim to avoid provoking their anger.

Recent studies on home advantage have looked at long-term trends. They show that while home advantage has decreased in all major sports, it has not declined as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s, home teams won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. One reason for this change could be travel. In the past, travel was difficult, but now players travel in great comfort, and if their hotel is not satisfactory, the club will find them a better one. Local conditions used to vary greatly, but now top stadiums are increasingly similar in their efficiency.

Despite these explanations, none fully explains the data. These changes, like pampered players and similar stadiums, have occurred relatively recently. The mystery remains as to why home advantage varies by sport. Basketball offers the most home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason could be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups between batter and pitcher. Team sports require coordination among teammates. In basketball, success depends on teamwork, which builds confidence in players' ability to work together at home, regardless of playing conditions.

Another possibility relates to a more primal aspect of sports. Researchers found that players' testosterone levels were normal before training and away games but increased by up to 67% before home games. This territorial instinct may connect to a basic urge to protect their home ground, as seen in recent Rugby World Cup matches. In two notable games, underdog teams won at home against stronger opponents, showing determination and aggression—key elements of home advantage. As one referee put it, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’'

"The more I practice, the luckier I get," said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying has become famous in sports and is appreciated by many dedicated athletes and their coaches. The quote's origin is often debated, with many claiming it was said by other golfers of that time. Its meaning is also unclear. Player was not talking about luck in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His true message was: "The more I practice, the better I become." However, there is a limit to this improvement, and the question of where that limit is relates to the nature-nurture debate—whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop through practice.

This discussion is not balanced; it heavily favors the idea that practice is more important than natural talent. This belief is largely based on the work of psychologist Anders Ericsson, who proposed that anyone can become an expert in any field with 10,000 hours of practice. His theory has inspired popular books like Malcolm Gladwell's "Outliers," as well as "Talent Is Overrated" and "Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice." These books generally agree that practice is the most important factor in achieving expertise, suggesting that 10,000 hours of practice is both necessary and enough to become an expert.

However, as Epstein discusses in his engaging book, this idea is often not true. He points out a significant flaw in much of the research on excellence: it usually focuses on already successful individuals. He asks if there are better ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not, and how to separate innate talent from factors like environment, support, opportunity, and determination.

Epstein travels around the world—from Kenya to Sweden, the Caribbean to the Arctic—to find answers. In Alaska, he discovers that the drive and desire of sled dogs in a tough race may be influenced by their genetics, suggesting a link between inherited traits and what we think of as voluntary characteristics. This raises the question: can commitment and determination be chosen, or are they also influenced by genetics?

Epstein emphasizes the complexity of this topic. He distinguishes between "hardware" (nature) and "software" (nurture), agreeing that both are essential for elite athletes. He does not deny the importance of training or environment. For example, he suggests that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. However, he also examines cases where genetics play a crucial role that cannot be overlooked.

Additionally, Epstein addresses the issues of race and gender in sports. He questions why we separate men and women in athletic competitions if only practice hours matter. Sometimes, the most important questions are the most obvious ones.

A recent international report shows that many children in rich, developed countries feel lonely, out of place, and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so unhappy? In her new book, Kith, Griffiths explains that these children spend too much time indoors, stuck in front of screens, whether watching TV or using computers. As a result, they have lost touch with nature – the woods, mountains, rivers, and streams. She believes this is the main issue. 

A follow-up study interviewed children to understand their feelings better. It found that many of them do not wish for the latest technology; instead, they would be happier if they could spend more time outside. Many adults over 40 often reminisce about their own childhoods, recalling how they enjoyed long summer days exploring, swimming, or building forts. They believe this was much healthier than the protected lives of today’s children. However, they often forget that they are the ones who created these protective environments for their kids, avoiding risks like building forts in old sheds.

Griffiths’ book contains strong arguments. She discusses how the fear of dangers in the outside world leads parents to keep their children at home, which benefits the toy and gadget industry that sells entertainment for indoor kids. She also criticizes trends like prescribing medication for restless children or requiring kids to wear goggles during traditional playground games. While I am unsure how common these strict rules are, Griffiths expresses her frustration with great passion. She also shares inspiring thoughts about childhood freedoms and limitations, from fairy tales to school rules.

However, Griffiths sometimes goes too far with her ideas and ignores important counterarguments. At one point, she even compares the modern treatment of children to a subtle form of racism, which seems extreme. She tends to have a romantic view of children, often overlooking their more challenging behaviors. For example, she claims that “children are the musicians of thought,” suggesting they would be creative if given the chance. While this might be true in some cases, it is not universally applicable.

One of the main themes of the book is that children should have the freedom to explore and take risks. Griffiths argues that children need to experience small accidents to learn how to handle bigger dangers later. However, she does not explain how to create these “right-sized” accidents. Additionally, not all children may want to follow the adventurous path Griffiths admires. What about those who are naturally shy or prefer staying at home? Perhaps the real issue is that we often try to fit all children into the same mold, whether by keeping them too safe or pushing them too hard.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and personal life, but this skill is not just from my education. Many life problems cannot be solved with complicated formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from real-life experiences. For children, these experiences often happen through play. 

My recent research focuses on how important play is for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young, and those that have the most to learn tend to play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because they rely more on learning than on instinct. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they are given the chance. 

Play is a natural way for both adults and mammals to learn. The most important skills children need to live happy and productive lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include thinking creatively, getting along with others, cooperating, and managing their own feelings. Creativity is essential for success in today’s economy. We no longer need people who simply follow instructions or perform routine calculations. Instead, we need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can encourage creative thinkers, we will have a strong workforce. 

However, we cannot teach creativity directly; it can be stifled by a school system that focuses on fixed questions and answers. More importantly, children need to learn how to interact with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children naturally want to play with each other, and through play, they develop social skills and learn about fairness and morality, which are important for their future. 

Play is voluntary, meaning players can choose to stop at any time. If they cannot quit, it is not truly play. Players understand that to keep the game enjoyable, they must make sure everyone is happy. This ability to quit makes play a very democratic activity. 

Unfortunately, school has become more demanding, with fewer breaks, more homework, and greater pressure for high grades. Outside of school, organized sports have taken the place of spontaneous games. Supervised playdates have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults often feel they must step in rather than let children solve their own problems. These changes have happened slowly but have had a significant impact over time. They are influenced by various social factors, including parents' fears, warnings from experts about dangers, less connected neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other.

Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the negative trend of the past fifty years. We need to give childhood back to children. They should be allowed to follow their natural instincts to play and explore, so they can grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more young people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to connect directly with potential employers, which is much easier than the old method of standing outside an office with a sign saying "hire me." However, this increased access also means there is a higher chance of making mistakes.

For example, a young job seeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many influential contacts, and the job seeker thought she could help him. However, the executive was offended by the idea of sharing her contacts with someone she didn’t know. She rejected his request and sent a sarcastic message that quickly spread online. Many people were shocked by her response, and she might regret her tone, if not her message. Yet, if this incident makes young people think more carefully about using social media for professional purposes, it could actually help them.

Social media can be a risky tool for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly, and many are making mistakes. Ironically, social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of young people's social lives for years. When my generation was young, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to impress others and create a different image of ourselves. You could have long conversations online and then ignore those people in real life. With the right pictures and songs on your Facebook page, you could seem like a more interesting person overnight. 

However, using social media for professional networking is very different, and some young people do not see this difference. We learned to be bold and confident online, which might explain why some still think this is a good approach. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you are worth hiring. We need to understand that what we learned about social networking as teenagers does not apply anymore, and we must meet employers' expectations to succeed in the job market.

One common complaint from employers about young job seekers on professional networking sites is that they are too casual and come across as arrogant. This reinforces the stereotype of young people as an "entitled generation." In reality, many of us are struggling to find jobs, which is why we are using social media. This perception of arrogance can hurt the job prospects of young people who actually have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing some research or helping in another way. This approach increases your chances of getting a positive response. Avoid sending generic messages, and keep your tone respectful to prevent leaving a bad impression. Remember, social media can be a great way to make important connections, but it requires careful use to avoid being ignored.

Anyone who claims they can accurately predict the future of newspapers is either lying or mistaken. The numbers show that newspapers are in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national daily newspapers has dropped by 30 to 50 percent. The Pew Research Centre in the USA reports that only 26 percent of US citizens now rely on newspapers for news, down from 45 percent in 2001. Many people confidently predict that the last printed newspaper will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that traditional media often survive longer than expected. 

In 1835, a journalist in New York claimed that books and theatre were finished and that newspapers would become the main source of social life. Yet, theatre has survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived even in the age of TV, and cinema has continued to do well against videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have made a comeback, with online sales increasing by 745 percent since 2008. 

Newspapers were once a new form of media, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news.
