When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good idea for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are usually popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked confused, he smiled and let me on the boat.

Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper swim of 1.5 km, which made me nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea.

Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own. 

The following days had a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful scenery. As the swims became longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat much anymore. I can hardly wait to come back again next year.

Being a flight attendant is not an easy job, but it has many rewards. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me!

As a child, I attended a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone at the beginning and end of each term. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed with me when I decided to leave my banking job and look for a new career.

At the interview for the flight attendant position, I saw many other young people, many of whom were also changing careers. They were often very qualified, just like me. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I wanted to stand out, so instead of just saying I loved to travel, I talked about my skills and past work experience. This approach helped me get the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because it has many benefits, although the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: "no one’s finished until everyone’s finished." It feels like a big family; even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close. When I’m off duty, I don’t have to take work home with me. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I remind myself that the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy watching the children achieve things they never thought they could. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some kids feel nervous at first, but with some encouragement, they decide to try, and in the end, they all reach the top. This makes them feel wonderful.

At the beginning of the week, some children miss their homes. Interestingly, it is not the younger ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We limit their use of mobile phones. We first tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, often after dinner, we say it is too late to call and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better after a couple of days, and by the end of their week, they come to us to say thank you because they have had a great time.

It is not just the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call frequently to check on their child, which is often unnecessary. Their child is usually busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to ask the parents to call back later.

We also notice a certain type of child who comes to camp, often dressed in expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something more appropriate, but soon they understand why it is necessary.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was difficult. The UK has stricter rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors based in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is larger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with audiences eager to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ I asked him what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’ 

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to join him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved that the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes! Although the young actors were already musicians, with some playing multiple instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie admitted that the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
